quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We dig into what product ops people do day to day, where the line is between their role and product management, whether you should consider getting into the role, whether your company would benefit from product ops.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets a practical agenda for evaluating product ops: responsibilities, boundaries with PM, career fit, and organizational need.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also have an interesting discussion around whether ops roles in general are a sign of inefficiency at your company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a contrarian lens practitioners can use to assess whether adding ops is solving root causes or masking process issues.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point about selectivity that signals quality control and competitive dynamics in the talent marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Ben Williams story and giving back
quotes.text: He said to me, "I bet you I'm not the only person who has these questions and I bet you I'm not the only person that's thinking about all these problems that probably seem very normal and natural."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A practical validation heuristic: if one team is struggling with “normal” problems, it’s likely widespread and worth systematizing.

quotes.topic_title: Ben Williams story and giving back
quotes.text: I really think there are a lot more people that you need to talk to about this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Actionable advice to scale learning: expand discovery beyond your team to uncover common patterns and build shared solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Ben Williams story and giving back
quotes.text: One of the best things that my first boss product always told me was, "You have to find a way to give back."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A guiding principle for practitioners: intentionally contribute back to the community as part of professional practice.

quotes.topic_title: Ben Williams story and giving back
quotes.text: When he said that to me, I was like, "I wonder if this is one of the ways that I can start to give back to the product community."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Connects personal motivation to a concrete mechanism—sharing learnings publicly—as a way to create broader impact.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops vs product management
quotes.text: One is it is a thing you do. Product operations for a VP or a head of product or a product manager is the creation of some system that allows you to thrive or allows your team to thrive in product management.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Defines product ops as an operational system/process any product leader can build, not just a job title.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops vs product management
quotes.text: The second is what we've seen more of over the last couple years, and it's the more common definition.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights the recent shift toward product ops being understood primarily as a dedicated role/team.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops vs product management
quotes.text: It's a person or the people, the group of individuals who are strong partners to the product manager and then for more mature product ops teams end up people being more strategic advisors to the head of products.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Gives a maturity model: from PM partners to strategic advisors to product leadership as the function evolves.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops vs product management
quotes.text: When it comes to data, qualitative, quantitative, anything that they feel can help the CPO or the head of product make more strategic decisions and well-informed decisions.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Clarifies product ops’ leverage point: synthesizing qualitative + quantitative inputs to improve executive decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
quotes.text: This is interesting, because as a former product manager and product leader, I don't think that things are new.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Reframes product ops as a response to long-standing product pains rather than a brand-new set of problems.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
quotes.text: So, the problems have always been there.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A concise mental model: product ops “emerged” because visibility/attention changed, not because the underlying issues did.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
quotes.text: But I will say that for me in particular at Pendo, it was the summer of 2019 that this really picked up and I remember a colleague of mine, shout out to Shannon. He's no longer with us, but he is one of the original people on the Pendo product team. He said, "I think this is the summer of the birth of product ops."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Pins the “2019 inflection” to a specific moment and internal observation, useful as a concrete example of the trend’s timing.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
quotes.text: All of a sudden, everybody's just like, "We need something. We need to make product better."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Captures the practical driver behind product ops adoption: organizations felt an urgent need to operationalize “making product better.”

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops emerged (the 2019 inflection)
quotes.text: So, for me, it went beyond the problems that we would solve as a product team with the Pendo product. It went into, "How can we help you as an organization solve pain that you're feeling within your product team that trickles out to the business?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Defines a product ops scope shift: from product/tool problems to organizational operating pain that impacts the broader business.

quotes.topic_title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
quotes.text: The customers started to come up and we started to feel it a bit more and I felt like there was this huge need for a voice of customer management and synthesis of both this qualitative and quantitative data as a theme that I saw arising across our customer base or even just folks that were reaching out about this role as they saw Pendo was putting it down.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights VoC synthesis (qual + quant) as a core driver and practical mandate for product ops.

quotes.topic_title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
quotes.text: There was a lot of pain around internal alignment in general, transparency to stakeholders up across your revenue team members.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Points to alignment and stakeholder transparency—especially with revenue teams—as a concrete problem product ops can solve.

quotes.topic_title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
quotes.text: All of these things I feel like made this perfect storm for product operations to come in and start calming things down.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Memorable framing of product ops as the stabilizing function amid PLG and rapid growth complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
quotes.text: Well, you can appoint a PM to liaise with other ops teams and the business, but at what risk?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Challenges the default approach of loading ops work onto PMs by calling out the hidden tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Drivers: VoC, alignment, PLG, rapid growth
quotes.text: CPOs went from deliver, deliver, deliver to really increased business metrics or just help drive the bottom line versus just really look at the product.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Captures the shift in product leadership expectations toward outcomes and business impact, implying new operating needs.

quotes.topic_title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
quotes.text: The way I've coached people to get around that is really, "What are your people responsible for? What are you holding them accountable to? Are you holding the product manager accountable to elevating these strategic insights so that they are going to elevate it to everyone else and then everyone else is going to go out there and build thing and drive the value or are you holding them accountable to truly understanding the customer in whatever way possible?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A practical accountability framing to prevent friction between PM and product ops by clarifying what PMs are truly responsible for.

quotes.topic_title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
quotes.text: Especially going on and talking to the customer, please don't let anybody ever take that for granted. Really spending time with their engineers and the customers in order to drive a better experience.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A reminder that direct customer contact and deep engineering collaboration are non-delegable PM activities even as ops support expands.

quotes.topic_title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
quotes.text: I think there's an art. You can do voice of customer in two ways.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model that VoC work should be adapted to the team’s maturity and product context rather than treated as one-size-fits-all.

quotes.topic_title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
quotes.text: So, Pendo's connected to Salesforce. We're connected to Looker. We're connected to all these different. So, what does the product manager need to achieve out of all those things that ultimately drives our experience for Pendo ourselves?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A concrete example of product ops owning the PM tool stack integrations and optimizing them around PM outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Core responsibilities: VoC, tooling, content, process
quotes.text: That's the bit that's a bit controversial, because folks are like, "Is this just program management? Is this just a different flavor of agile?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights a common (and contentious) boundary question about whether product ops should own process facilitation versus traditional program/agile roles.

quotes.topic_title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
quotes.text: What we found that there was just not this need for the revenue org to be transparent and say, "Hey, this is what we're hearing. Product people, please listen," or vice versa.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights transparency as a deliberate VoC mechanism to break down silos between product and revenue teams.

quotes.topic_title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
quotes.text: There was this interesting moment where we realized that our sales team was screaming for something and our success team was screaming for something else, but [inaudible 00:16:46] looking at something else.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A concrete example of misalignment that VoC can surface by comparing themes across internal customer-facing teams.

quotes.topic_title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
quotes.text: Our PMs, they would get the whole readout with us, but we brought those folks in a room together.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: run cross-functional VoC readouts as a shared forum, not just a report to PMs.

quotes.topic_title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
quotes.text: But the PM got risk data, high-priority deals, feedback from our feedback product. What are we hearing from prospects versus paying customers. What segments are saying what?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A practical VoC input framework: combine deal risk + priority revenue signals + segmented feedback across prospect/customer types.

quotes.topic_title: How Pendo runs voice of customer
quotes.text: But on the other side, what was really nice too was we were able to educate our revenue team on behalf of the product team and say, "Guys, not everything requires a product change."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Counterintuitive VoC outcome: use customer feedback to drive enablement/documentation fixes—not just product roadmap changes.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops relationship with user research
quotes.text: They report into our head of UX and they are responsible for proactive research and making sure that we are aligning to our strategy and saying, "Okay, here's what our folks are saying. Here's why we're going after this market or this new thing that we're doing. Let's start going out there and validating or checking with some of these key personas and what we need to do."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Clarifies a practical model for UX research: proactive validation tied directly to strategy and persona checks.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops relationship with user research
quotes.text: So, they sit as a partner to us. We work very closely together.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Emphasizes that product ops and user research should operate as close partners rather than separate functions.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops relationship with user research
quotes.text: Again, I'll give you that example of voice of customer, which is we have all of this input coming in from our customer success or post-sales teams and we know we're about to invest in our guides area of the product. We have all of these. What do we do with it?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Gives a concrete “voice of customer” workflow trigger: aggregating post-sales inputs ahead of an investment decision.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops relationship with user research
quotes.text: Well, we couple that with I'm personal responsible for NPS or I was for a very long time. I'm seeing a lot of noise around guides.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Shows how product ops can combine qualitative feedback with NPS signal monitoring to spot themes worth investigating.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops relationship with user research
quotes.text: So, I take all of that, we pull it all together, and we give it to our head of research and say, "All right. Let's all make sense of all this together. Is this something that is in line with the direction that the product team is going, the guides team, or is this something that we're going to need to dig a little bit more into to see if their efforts right now where they're growing are not where there should be going?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Provides an actionable collaboration pattern: product ops aggregates signals and partners with research to interpret alignment vs. deeper investigation needs.

quotes.topic_title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
quotes.text: I would say it's more, "What are the things that the product manager needs in order to be successful?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Reframes product ops tooling from process optimization to enabling PM success outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
quotes.text: So, it's more about the PM's tool stack versus the PM's planning tool stack if you want to draw that distinction.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Introduces a useful mental model separating planning tools from the broader operational tool ecosystem PMs rely on.

quotes.topic_title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
quotes.text: I mentioned earlier treating content is a part of the development lifecycle process. You really want to treat it as a part of definition of done.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to operationalize documentation and in-app education as a required ship criterion.

quotes.topic_title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
quotes.text: When you think about product-led growth and the emergence of that in particular over the last couple years, it's all about creating that experience and keeps people in and helps them upgrade.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Connects PLG outcomes (retention and upgrade) directly to intentional in-product education and experience design.

quotes.topic_title: Tooling and content strategy in practice
quotes.text: So, they work alongside product marketing to develop these playbooks for what they're doing in app to create less friction and drive more engagement.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Concrete operating model: product ops + product marketing co-create in-app playbooks to reduce friction and increase engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Is product ops only for B2B?
quotes.text: My personal experience and I think a lot of people would agree with me has led me to believe that's not accurate.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Directly challenges the assumption that product ops is primarily a B2B function.

quotes.topic_title: Is product ops only for B2B?
quotes.text: Without calling out names, there were some really big companies in retail and finance and some industries that you would not expect who are B2C, larger, well established companies who we all know and love and maybe not even love.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Grounds the argument in a concrete (if anonymized) example that B2C enterprises also need product ops due to complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Is product ops only for B2B?
quotes.text: I think the common thread is the cross-functional transparency and then transparency out to the customer.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Offers a simple mental model for when product ops is valuable: transparency internally and externally.

quotes.topic_title: Is product ops only for B2B?
quotes.text: So, I mentioned transparency is a big word for us, but readiness is another one and so readiness means a lot.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Introduces “readiness” as a key operational lens for product teams beyond just building features.

quotes.topic_title: Is product ops only for B2B?
quotes.text: You have your teams you need to get ready internally, but you really need to get customers ready for something new as well and everybody needs to feel aligned.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: treat launches as dual readiness workstreams (internal teams + customers) with alignment as the goal.

quotes.topic_title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
quotes.text: Yeah, I go back to that question that I have asked leaders when helping them stand this up, which is what are you looking at your PMs to drive and how are you measuring their success? That generally just helps everybody get on the same page really quickly.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A practical alignment question to reduce PM resistance by clarifying PM accountability and success metrics before defining product ops.

quotes.topic_title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
quotes.text: Generally, I will tell you it's because they still have a bit of buying in the top to get done.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A diagnosis for why product ops implementations stall: the missing ingredient is executive-level sponsorship, not PM persuasion tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
quotes.text: I'm seeing that the most successful ones that are drawing the lines and showing that this role is valuable are the people that have their buy-in from their CEO or CPO at that level or their head of product and saying, "Hey, this is what this role means for you."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A concrete pattern for getting buy-in: secure top-level backing so the role’s boundaries and value are clearly communicated.

quotes.topic_title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
quotes.text: Yeah. Number one, do you want your PMs to constantly be fielding questions from your revenue team when they could be spending time with customers?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A compelling, outcome-oriented selling point for product ops: protect PM time from revenue-team firefighting to focus on customers.

quotes.topic_title: Getting buy-in and avoiding PM resistance
quotes.text: Yeah, I can count on one hand the companies who have blocked their product managers from speaking to customers and those companies are not product companies. I mean they do not believe in product management. They might say they do, but they don't.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A sharp, contrarian litmus test that challenges orgs claiming to be product-led while preventing PM-customer contact.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should never offload
quotes.text: Speaking as a former PM, I would not ever give up spending time with customers and watching their pain.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Defines the non-delegable core of product management as direct customer exposure and empathy-building.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should never offload
quotes.text: That's how I fell in love with product was I saw my internal customer 10, 12 years back now fighting with the keyboard, fighting with the mouse.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A concrete example of how observing real user struggle can reveal product gaps and motivate improvement.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should never offload
quotes.text: I think it was an experience that some people might say, "Oh, I never want to be in that situation again because it made me feel very uncomfortable that my product is not doing for this person what it needs to," but for me, it was, "How do I make this thing do what it needs to for this gentleman? How do I make this thing better?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Reframes discomfort from user pain as a productive trigger for iteration rather than something to avoid.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should never offload
quotes.text: I cannot see product managers saying, "I don't want to be a part of that conversation." Then you know what? I'm going to say it then don't be in product.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A hard-line standard that challenges PMs to treat customer conversations as essential, not optional.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should never offload
quotes.text: We talked about put yourself onto not disturb mode and I learned a long time ago, put myself onto disturb mode. So, imagine having a partner that helps you filter that noise.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive operating model: stay open to inputs but rely on a system/partner (e.g., product ops) to triage noise.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
quotes.text: So, imagine having a partner that helps you filter that noise.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Frames product ops as a practical “noise filter” that helps PMs focus amid constant distractions and inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
quotes.text: It's a PM. It's PM.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Clarifies that the work product ops often takes on is fundamentally PM work, not a separate adjacent discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
quotes.text: because what I'm seeing in less mature product orgs who first bring in product ops, the first thing they ask them to do is streamline the planning process.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable pattern for early product ops hires: they’re commonly pulled into planning/process standardization first.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
quotes.text: But again, in lesser mature orgs, the first thing is, "How do I actually just get the people to plan the same way and give me the thing that they're planning and doing?"
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights a specific operational pain point product ops can address immediately: consistent planning artifacts and visibility across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs program management and agile roles
quotes.text: The only thing that distinguishes product operations folks from program managers and agile is that product operations people know, understand the product, the customer, and the inner workings of the business.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Defines a clear differentiation framework: product ops isn’t just facilitation—it requires deep product/customer/business understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
quotes.text: So, to say ops teams are generally a sign of inefficiency or the need for them is a sign of inefficiency is not always accurate, it's generally a sign of growth and opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Reframes the “ops = inefficiency” take by positioning ops as a natural response to organizational growth and complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
quotes.text: we as product ops want to and should be standing up whatever processes or systems are needed and then get out of the way so we can focus on driving more strategic value.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for product ops: build scalable systems, then step back and move up the value chain.

quotes.topic_title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
quotes.text: I myself recently switched roles here at Pendo because I did what I said I was going to do, which was stand up the system, stand up the things that we knew we needed to do that were going to either be given off to another team or automated and then get the rest of the humans that are here to do the other strategic things for the product team.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Concrete example of designing ops work to be handed off/automated, freeing people to focus on higher-leverage strategic impact.

quotes.topic_title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
quotes.text: So, for years when I was interviewing folks from my team, I made that one point abundantly clear to them, get into this role if you're comfortable letting go of things and moving on to something that is well worth your time.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Hiring guidance: successful ops practitioners must be comfortable deprecating their own work and continuously shifting to new problems.

quotes.topic_title: Are ops roles a sign of inefficiency?
quotes.text: Maybe ChatGPT is going to make things very clear that humans are not always going to be doing the same things and we need to focus our energy elsewhere, but people do need to get comfortable with that role.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights automation/AI as an accelerant for ops evolution, pushing teams to proactively re-scope human work toward higher-value areas.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold. If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a gating factor for enterprise sales and deal velocity, making compliance a revenue enabler rather than just a security checkbox.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Beginning a SOC 2 report can be a huge burden, especially for startups. It's time-consuming, tedious, and expensive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the practical cost/effort reality of SOC 2 so teams can plan resourcing and timelines appropriately.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast-growing, companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and a quantified claim about automation leverage for SOC 2 work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific time-to-value benchmark practitioners can use when evaluating compliance tooling and timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
quotes.text: Well, there's two things. There's the knowing something's coming and then there's the knowing what to do with it.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for launch readiness: awareness isn’t enough—teams must be enabled to act.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
quotes.text: You can use just some status keeping thing to say, "This is coming in Q4 and as we get closer, here's the date," but it's what to do with it and how to position it and how to talk about it and all the things that was missing from it.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that “status updates” don’t create readiness; teams need positioning, messaging, and execution support.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
quotes.text: So, I truly believe with a really healthy product operations person or team, you have that ability to impact change across the company.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Defines product ops as a cross-company change lever, not just a product-team support function.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
quotes.text: All I said in that moment was we need to create a system so that this doesn't happen again.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Reframes a “bad launch” response from blaming individuals to building repeatable systems.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you need product ops: transparency and readiness
quotes.text: It does not have to be humans. It can be that there's a system being created that is from a strong product person who knows how to get this team to be healthy.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: you can implement product ops via process/system design before hiring a dedicated team.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
quotes.text: It's really not easy to measure this in a quantitative measure just yet.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Highlights the practical reality that product ops impact often can’t be cleanly quantified early on, pushing teams toward proxy measures.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
quotes.text: So, what we did was we looked at that transparency problem.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Frames measurement as starting from diagnosing a core operational problem (transparency) rather than chasing generic metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
quotes.text: We sent out this survey across both product managers and the sales and success teams and we said, "Where's your time going, PMs? How much time are you giving on average to the revenue team to firefight? How much time do you with customers that's quality time."
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, replicable measurement method: survey PMs on time allocation to quantify firefighting vs. quality customer time.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
quotes.text: Then on the flip side to the revenue team, how many times do you find yourself asking questions?
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Introduces an inbound-quality proxy metric by measuring question volume from revenue teams as a signal of transparency gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring impact: inbound quality and surveys
quotes.text: I go back to this whole people can know when they're coming, but they need to know what it is they need to do with it.
quotes.speaker: Christine Itwaru
quotes.context: Memorable guidance that transparency isn’t just timelines—it's enabling action by clarifying what stakeholders should do with the information.
